title: Ph.D., Quantitative Ecology - Incomplete
loc: Purdue University  \nAdvisor: Dr. Pat Zollner
description_1: Dissertation: Develop an agent-based model to estimate the effectiveness of chronic wasting disease management methods on Odocoileus virginianus populations

title: M.Sc.,  Natural Resources Ecology and Management
loc: Oklahoma State University  \nAdvisors: Dr's. Julia Earl & Sam Fuhlendorf
description_1: Thesis: Examined the effects of the Conservation Reserve Program and anthropogenic structures on the long-distance movements of Tympanuchus pallidicinctus
description_3: Utilized resource selection function's (mixed-model conditional logistic regression), semi-variogram-based movement models, and a emperical distribution function-based method to estimate selection-avoidance-neutral trends in response to features in the landscape.
description_5: Experience applying mixed-effect regression models and a variety of spatial movement and selection models.

title: B.S., Fish, Wildlife and Conservation Biology
loc: Colorado State University
description_1: Concentration: Wildlife Biology

title: GRE Scores
description_1: Quantitative Reasoning: 157

title: Graduate Teaching/Research Assistant
loc: Purdue University \nZollner Lab
description_1: Create and parameterize an agent-based model to simulate the distribution and movement of Odocoileus virginianus.
description_2: Simulate chronic wasting disease spread in the population and discover what control methods may stop or slow the disease expansion.
description_3: Utilized machine learning methods such as random forests and decision trees to draw conclusions from the simulation results.
description_4: Began development of an agent-based model to estimate the effectiveness of chronic wasting disease management methods on Odocoileus virginianus
description_5: Continued education by taking graduate level coursework in statistics and data science

title: Student Consultant
loc: Oklahoma State University and Purdue University
description_1: Worked unnoffically as a consultant for GIS and R within my graduate school departments helping other students, post docs, and research staff improve their R programming skills, tidy data and manage data with unit tests, and perform statistical and spatial analyses.
description_2: I have led help sessions one on one, within small working groups, and given detailed presentations about new techniques to lab research groups and graduate level classes.

title: Graduate Research Assistant
loc: Oklahoma State University \nFuhlendorf and Earl Labs
description_1: Created an algorithm in R to separate long-distance movement tracts from home range movements using GPS locations of 350 individual lesser prarie-chickens.
description_2: Utilized resource selection function's (mixed-model logistic regression), semi-variogram-based movement models, and a cumulative distribution function-based method to estimate selection-avoidance-neutral trends in response to features in the landscape.
description_3: This information will be used to inform models of connectivity between LPC populations and allow for the management of gene flow and dispersal in a fragmented landscape.
description_4: Experience applying mixed-effect regression models and a variety of spatial movement and selection models.

title: Human Dimensions Technician
loc: Colorado Parks and Wildlife \nSupervisor: Dr. Stacy Lischka
description_1: *Projects:* Examining angler satisfaction in Colorado, assessing motivations of Colorado big game hunters, black bear exploitation of urban environments, assessing motivations of Colorado waterfowl hunters, examine the outdoor oriented values of elementary students using an Outdoor Wilderness Lab, track the effect of implementing a novice hunter program in Colorado
description_2: Worked on a variety of interdisciplinary projects in social science and natural resources to create summary reports for survey data, literature reviews, statistical and spatial analysis of survey response data, and  designed and managed Access and ESRI geodatabases.

title: NSF - Research Experience for Undergraduates Fellow
loc: University of Kansas  \nReuman Lab
description_1: Used SQL and R to parse a 150 year-old fish stomach database to create a food web for the North Atlantic Ocean and test for correlation in these interspecific relationships with meta-population synchrony.

title: GIS & Human Dimensions Independent Study
loc: Colorado Parks and Wildlife & Colorado State University \nSupervisor's: Dr's. Stacy Lischka and Yu Wei
description_1: Worked to develop a method to spatially model and predict human attitudes and tolerance to black bears using survey response data.
description_2: Experience using SQL to interface with a database and Python & R to script a spatially-explicit model.
description_3: Began development of a method to spatially model and predict human attitudes and tolerance to black bears using survey response data.

title: Predictive Model for Archeological Sites Affected by Flood Damage
loc: SIM Minor Capstone Project (CSU)
description_1: Designed a predictive model to locate prehistoric and historic cultural sites in the Eastern foothills of the Rocky Mountains in Colorado using ArcGIS and python scripts.
description_2: Created for National Forest Service archeologists.
description_3: This initial model was designed to be scalable in order to  locate cultural sites in a variety of terrains.
description_4: Designed a predictive model to locate prehistoric and historic cultural archeological sites using spatial predictors with ArcGIS and python scripts.

title: Field Technician - Mule Deer Neonate Capture
loc: Colorado Parks and Wildlife  \nSupervisor: Mark Peterson
description_1: Used telemetry and GPS to locate does and monitor for birth timing. Captured, measured, and collared mule deer neonates. Monitored collared fawns for mortality signals and investigated the cause of death.
description_2: Assisted in the capture and tagging of neonate deer.
description_3: Used VHF and Iridium GPS telemetry to monitor individual survival and assess cause of mortality.

title: Field Technician - White-tailed Deer Capture
loc: Missouri Department of Conservation  \nSupervisor: Jon McRoberts
description_1: Captured, measured, and collared adult deer using Clover traps and rocket nets. VITs were inserted in does for neonate capture. Used telemetry and GPS to locate dropped collars and find mortalities.
description_2: Neonates were captured and collared using GPS locations retrieved from collars and monitoring VIT and doe collar VHF frequencies.
description_3: All collared deer were monitored for mortality using Iridium GPS network or VHF signals.
description_4: Assisted in the capture and tagging of adult and neonate deer.
description_5: Used VHF and Iridium GPS telemetry to monitor individual survival and movement patterns.

title: Vertebrate Population Dynamics
loc: Purdue Department of Forestry and Natural Resources
